revisions.rev:
{{NCAATeamFootballSeason |Year=2007 |Team=UCF Knights |Image=University of Central Florida UCF vertical text logo.svg |ImageSize=100px |Conference=Conference USA |Division=East |ShortConference=C-USA |Record=10-4 |ConfRecord=8-1 |CoachRank= |APRank= |HeadCoach=[[George O'Leary]] |OffCoach=Tim Salem |DefCoach=John Skladany |OScheme= |DScheme= |StadiumArena=[[Bright House Networks Stadium]] |Champion=C-USA Champions
C-USA East Division Champions |ConfChamp=[[2007 Conference USA Football Championship Game|C-USA Championship Game]] |ConfChampResult= W 44-25 vs. [[Tulsa Golden Hurricanes football|Tulsa]] |BowlTourney= [[2007 Liberty Bowl]] |BowlTourneyResult= L 3-10 vs. [[2007 Mississippi State Bulldogs football team|Mississippi State]] }} {{2007 Conference USA football standings}} The '''2007 UCF Knights football team''' represented the [[University of Central Florida]] in the [[2007 NCAA Division I FBS football season]]. Their head coach is [[George O'Leary]]. 2007 was the first year the [[UCF Knights football|UCF Knights]] played all of their home games at [[Bright House Networks Stadium]], which they had just opened on the main campus of UCF in [[Orlando, Florida]]. The Knights were led on offense by [[quarterback]] [[Kyle Israel]] and Consensus All-American [[running back]] [[Kevin Smith (running back)|Kevin Smith]].{{cite news | url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/player/profile?playerId=157896 | title=#7 Kyle Israel | QB | work=ESPN.com | publisher=The Disney Company | accessdate=2007-09-15}}{{cite news | url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/sports/college/knights/orl-fbcucffolo0307sep03,0,7398981.story | title=UCF upbeat as date with Texas looms | work=OrlandoSentinel.com | publisher=Tribune Company |author=Hightower, Kyle | date=September 3, 2007 | accessdate=2007-09-15}} UCF sought to prove they belonged on the big stage, and got their first chance by hosting the [[2007 Texas Longhorns football team|Texas Longhorns]], ultimately losing by only a field goal. UCF ultimately went 9-3 in the regular season and 7-1 in C-USA, with their only conference loss being at [[2007 East Carolina Pirates football team|East Carolina]], and won the Eastern Division. They would go on to host their second [[2007 Conference USA Football Championship Game|Conference USA Championship]]. Taking revenge on [[2007 Tulsa Golden Hurricane football team|Tulsa]] for beating them two years before, UCF won the game, 44-25, to take their first Conference USA title. They would go on to their first [[2007 Liberty Bowl|Liberty Bowl]] berth against [[2007 Mississippi State Bulldogs football team|Mississippi State]]. Their defense held it close, but the offense was unable to re-fire, and UCF lost the game, 10-3. Kevin Smith would ultimately forego his senior year and go to the [[2008 NFL Draft]], where he was selected with the first pick of the third round by the [[Detroit Lions]], the highest Knight to go in the draft since [[Daunte Culpepper]] in 1999. ==Schedule== {{CFB Schedule Start | ranklink=yes | time=yes | tv=yes | rank=no | attend=yes }} {{CFB Schedule Entry | date = September 1 | nonconf = yes | homecoming = | time = 6:00pm | away = yes | opponent = [[2007 NC State Wolfpack football team|NC State]] | rank = no | site_stadium = [[Carter-Finley Stadium]] | site_cityst = [[Raleigh, North Carolina]] | tv = [[ESPN360]] | w/l = w | score = 25-23 | attend = 57,283 }} {{CFB Schedule Entry | date = September 15 | nonconf = yes | homecoming = | time = 3:30pm | opponent = [[2007 Texas Longhorns football team|Texas]] | opprank = 6 | rank = no | site_stadium = Bright House Networks Stadium | site_cityst = Orlando, FL | tv = [[ESPN2]] | w/l = l | score = 35-32 | attend = 45,622 }} {{CFB Schedule Entry | date = September 22 | nonconf = no | homecoming = | time = 3:30pm | opponent = {{cfb link|year=2007|team=Memphis Tigers|title=Memphis}} | rank = no | site_stadium = Bright House Networks Stadium | site_cityst = Orlando, FL | tv = [[Comcast Sports Southeast/Charter Sports Southeast|CSS]] | w/l = w | score = 56-20 | attend = 42,153 }} {{CFB Schedule Entry | date = September 29 | nonconf = yes | homecoming = | time = 6:00pm | opponent = {{cfb link|year=2007|team=Louisiana-Lafayette Ragin' Cajuns|title=UL-Lafayette}} | rank = no | site_stadium = Bright House Networks Stadium | site_cityst = Orlando, FL | tv = - | w/l =w | score = 37-19 | attend = 42,646 }} {{CFB Schedule Entry | date = October 6 | nonconf = no | homecoming = | time = 7:30pm | away = yes | opponent = [[2007 East Carolina Pirates football team|East Carolina]] | rank = no | site_stadium = [[Dowdy-Ficklen Stadium]] | site_cityst = [[Greenville, North Carolina]] | tv = [[CSTV]] | w/l = l | score = 52-38 | attend = 42,777 }} {{CFB Schedule Entry | date = October 13 | nonconf = yes | homecoming = | time = 12:00pm | away = yes | opponent = [[2007 South Florida Bulls football team|South Florida]] | opprank = 5 | rank = no | site_stadium = [[Raymond James Stadium]] | site_cityst = [[Tampa, FL]] | gamename = [[The War on I-4 (college football)|The War on I-4]] | tv = [[ESPNU]] | w/l = l | score = 64-12 | attend = 65,948 }} {{CFB Schedule Entry | date = October 20 | nonconf = no | homecoming = | time = 4:00pm | opponent = {{cfb link|year=2007|team=Tulsa Golden Hurricane|title=Tulsa}} | rank = no | site_stadium = Bright House Networks Stadium | site_cityst = Orlando, FL | tv = - | w/l = w | score = 44-23 | attend = 45,510 }} {{CFB Schedule Entry | date = October 28 | nonconf = no | homecoming = | time = 8:00pm | away = yes | opponent = [[2007 Southern Miss Golden Eagles football team|Southern Miss]] | rank = no | site_stadium = [[M. M. Roberts Stadium]] | site_cityst = [[Hattiesburg, MS]] | tv = [[ESPN]] | w/l = w | score = 34-17 | attend = 27,103 }} {{CFB Schedule Entry | date = November 3 | nonconf = no | homecoming = yes | time = 3:30pm | opponent = {{cfb link|year=2007|team=Marshall Thundering Herd|title=Marshall}} | rank = no | site_stadium = Bright House Networks Stadium | site_cityst = Orlando, FL | tv = [[Comcast Sports Southeast/Charter Sports Southeast|CSS]] | w/l = w | score = 47-13 | attend = 46,103 }} {{CFB Schedule Entry | date = November 10 | nonconf = no | homecoming = | time = 7:30pm | away = yes | opponent = [[2007 UAB Blazers football team|UAB]] | rank = no | site_stadium = [[Legion Field]] | site_cityst = [[Birmingham, AL]] | tv = [[CSTV]] | w/l = w | score = 45-31 | attend = 12,621 }} {{CFB Schedule Entry | date = November 17 | nonconf = no | homecoming = | time = 3:00pm | away = yes | opponent = {{cfb link|year=2007|team=SMU Mustangs|title=SMU}} | rank = no | site_stadium = [[Gerald J. Ford Stadium]] | site_cityst = [[Dallas, TX]] | tv = | w/l = w | score = 49-20 | attend = 10,271 }} {{CFB Schedule Entry | date = November 24 | nonconf = no | homecoming = | time = 12:00pm | opponent = [[2007 UTEP Miners football team|UTEP]] | rank = no | site_stadium = Bright House Networks Stadium | site_cityst = Orlando, FL | tv = [[CSTV]] | w/l = w | score = 36-20 | attend = 41,967 }} {{CFB Schedule Entry | date = December 1 | nonconf = no | homecoming = | time = 12:00pm | opponent = {{cfb link|year=2007|team=Tulsa Golden Hurricane|title=Tulsa}} | gamename = [[Conference USA Football Championship|C-USA Championship]] | rank = no | site_stadium = Bright House Networks Stadium | site_cityst = Orlando, FL | tv = [[ESPN]] | w/l = w | score = 44-25 | attend = 44,128 }} {{CFB Schedule Entry | date = December 29 | nonconf = no | homecoming = | time = 4:30pm | opponent = [[2007 Mississippi State Bulldogs football team|Mississippi State]] | gamename = [[2007 Liberty Bowl|Liberty Bowl]] | rank = no | site_stadium = [[Liberty Bowl Memorial Stadium]] | site_cityst = [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis, TN]] | tv = [[ESPN]] | w/l = l | score = 10-3 | attend = 63,816 }} {{CFB Schedule End|poll=[[Associated Press]]|timezone=[[North American Eastern Time Zone|Eastern Time]]|rank=no}} ==Game Summaries== ===Week 1: North Carolina State (September 1)=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road='''UCF''' |R1=15 |R2=10 |R3=0 |R4=0 |Home=NC State |H1=0 |H2=3 |H3=7 |H4=13 }} The [[NC State Wolfpack]] played the Knights for the first game of the season. This is the first game where the UCF Knights played with their new logo and white helmet, and also marked UCF's first win over an ACC opponent ever, and was the first win over a BCS team since George O'Leary became head coach. {{-}} ===Week 2: Bye=== Bye ===Week 3: Texas (September 15)=== [[Image:UCF offense against UT line.jpg|right|thumb|UCF on offense against Texas]] {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=#6 '''Texas''' |R1=10 |R2=10 |R3=3 |R4=12 |Home=UCF |H1=7 |H2=3 |H3=7 |H4=15 }} [[Image:Texas at UCF game over.jpg|right|thumb|[[Bright House Networks Stadium]] at [[twilight]].]] {{seealso|2007 Texas Longhorn football team}} This was the first ever meeting between the [[2007 Texas Longhorns football team|Texas Longhorns]] and the UCF Knights.{{cite news | url=http://www.mackbrown-texasfootball.com/index.php?s=&url_channel_id=36&url_subchannel_id=&url_article_id=298&change_well_id=2 | title=All Time Record vs. Opponents | publisher=MackBrownTexasFootball | accessdate=2007-03-31}} Texas was the first opponent in the Knights new stadium, [[Bright House Networks Stadium]], and the 2007 game is the first of three scheduled meetings between the schools.{{cite news | url=http://ucfathletics.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/050906aaa.html | title=UCF Football to Face Texas in New On-Campus Stadium in 2007 - 2005 national champs will be first opponent in new stadium. | publisher=UCF Athletic Department | date=9 May 2006 | accessdate=2006-10-22}} During the game, [[lightning]] spotted near the stadium caused a fifteen minute delay.{{cite news | title=College Football - Texas at Central Florida | work=ESPN2 | publisher=The Disney Company | date=September 15, 2007}}. The game was a back-and-forth contest. Texas took an early three point lead and then UCF made a touchdown to go ahead 7 3. The Longhorns led 20 10 at half-time, but the Knights came back to take a 24 23 lead early in the fourth quarter. Texas then scored two field goals and a touchdown and appeared to be on the way to running out the clock before a [[Jamaal Charles]] fumble gave the Knights the ball back with about two minutes left in the game. UCF made a touchdown and a two-point conversion to cut Texas' lead to 35–32 with 35 seconds remaining. When the Knights were unable to recover their onside kick attempt, Texas was able to run out the clock and preserve their three-point victory.{{cite news | url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/playbyplay?gameId=272582116&period=0 | title=(6) Texas 35, UCF 32 Play-by-play | work=ESPNU.com | publisher=The Disney Company | date=September 15, 2007 | accessdate=2007-09-15}}{{cite news | url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/drivechart?gameId=272582116 | title=(6) Texas 35, UCF 32 Drive chart | work=ESPNU.com | publisher=The Disney Company | date=September 15, 2007 | accessdate=2007-09-15}} Jamaal Charles of Texas rushed 22 times for 157 yards and UCF's [[Kevin Smith (running back)|Kevin Smith]] rushed 27 times for 150 yards for UCF. UT's [[Colt McCoy]] completed 68% of his passes for a total of 227 yards; UCF's [[Kyle Israel]] completed 35% of his passes for a total of 133 yards. Texas ran 47 passing plays and 43 rushing plays to UCF's 26 plays passing and 41 rushing attempts.{{cite news | url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/boxscore?gameId=272582116 | title=(6) Texas 35, UCF 32 Box Score | work=ESPNU.com | publisher=The Disney Company | date=September 15, 2007 | accessdate=2007-09-15}} {{-}} ===Week 4: Memphis (September 22)=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road= Memphis |R1=0 |R2=0 |R3=6 |R4=14 |Home='''UCF''' |H1=14 |H2=28 |H3=7 |H4=7 }} This was the first [[Conference USA]] game for both teams. UCF took a strong lead early in the game, with the halftime score at 42-0, and a lead at one point of 49-0. The UCF Knights have beaten Memphis every time they have played them since joining Conference USA three years ago. During the game Kyle Israel and freshman Michael Greco were used in tandem at quarterback, and their success in the game drew immediate comparisons to [[Chris Leak]] and [[Tim Tebow]] at [[2007 Florida Gators football team|Florida]] the previous year. {{-}} ===Week 5: Louisiana-Lafayette (September 29)=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=UL-Lafayette |R1=3 |R2=3 |R3=7 |R4=6 |Home='''UCF''' |H1=10 |H2=20 |H3=7 |H4=0 }} UCF again took a command lead of 30-6 into halftime, but this time permitting the winless Louisiana-Lafayette team within 20 was more concerning. After the game, Coach O'Leary resolved to remind his team of the importance of playing hard all four quarters of the game, which would be important especially with two road games coming up. {{-}} ===Week 6: East Carolina (October 6)=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=UCF |R1=14 |R2=14 |R3=3 |R4=7 |Home='''East Carolina''' |H1=7 |H2=10 |H3=28 |H4=7 }} After going into the half up 28-17, UCF took a surprising downturn with five turnovers in the third quarter: 2 Kyle Israel interceptions, one Michael Greco interception, and two lost fumbles between Israel and running back Kevin Smith. ECU outscored UCF 28-3 in the third to take the win. {{-}} ===Week 7: South Florida (October 13)=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=UCF |R1=7 |R2=3 |R3=0 |R4=2 |Home=#5 '''South Florida''' |H1=12 |H2=17 |H3=14 |H4=21 }} {{seealso|2007 South Florida Bulls football team}} {{seealso|The War on I-4 (college football)}} South Florida came into the game ranked #5 in both the [[AP Poll|AP]] and [[Coaches Poll]]s going into the game, but UCF would not hold the game as close as they did when they faced then-#6 Texas. UCF scored their only offensive pointsâa Kyle Israel rush for a touchdown, and a field goalâin the first half. UCF and USF would also exchange [[safety (American football score)|safeties]], but South Florida held a commanding lead at halftime and proceeded to rout the Knights in the second half, with USF's second- and third-string QBs throwing long touchdown passes against a demoralized UCF defense enroute to a 64-12 thrashing of the Knights. UCF was held to just 145 yards total offense, while South Florida used several big plays to dominate the UCF defense, advancing 543 total yards even though UCF controlled the ball for three minutes longer than South Florida. South Florida emerged #2 in the [[Bowl Championship Series|BCS]] and [[AP Poll]]s, and #3 in the [[Coaches Poll|Coaches]] and [[Harris Interactive College Football Poll|Harris Poll]]s. {{-}} ===Week 8: Tulsa (October 20)=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Tulsa |R1=14 |R2=3 |R3=0 |R4=6 |Home='''UCF''' |H1=7 |H2=17 |H3=7 |H4=13 }} UCF broke free of the two-game losing streak at home against the Tulsa Golden Hurricane, taking the lead in the 2nd quarter and never looking back. Kyle Israel completed 21 of 29 for 229 yards, passing and running for touchdowns, and Kevin Smith rushed for 178 yards with three running touchdowns, catching another. Michael Torres kicked three field goals. {{-}} ===Week 9: Southern Miss (October 28)=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road='''UCF''' |R1=7 |R2=14 |R3=10 |R4=3 |Home=Southern Miss |H1=7 |H2=3 |H3=7 |H4=0 }} UCF's defense intercepted Southern Miss QB [[Stephen Reaves]] three times, and Kevin Smith ran the ball a UCF-record 43 times for 175 yards and two touchdowns. Smith reasserted himself as the nation's #2 rusher, and the Junior tailback took the school's career rushing yards record (3,372). UCF minimized its mistakes, getting through the game without turning the ball over for the first time since their first game against NC State. {{-}} ===Week 10: Marshall (November 3)=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Marshall |R1=0 |R2=3 |R3=3 |R4=7 |Home='''UCF''' |H1=10 |H2=17 |H3=0 |H4=20 }} This was the Homecoming game for UCF, and was the first time that all of the Homecoming festivities, including the Homecoming parade, occurred on campus. The Knights rolled over the Herd in this game. {{-}} ===Week 11: Alabama-Birmingham (November 10)=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road='''UCF''' |R1=10 |R2=7 |R3=14 |R4=14 |Home=UAB |H1=14 |H2=3 |H3=7 |H4=7 }} UCF traveled to Birmingham and went on to defeat UAB in a hard fought game. The 2-8 Blazers proved troublesome for the Knights, but UCF finished them off towards the end of the fourth quarter. Earlier in the day, Marshall defeated ECU giving UCF the lead in the C-USA East Division, and due to a blowout win over Houston by Tulsa, the Knights are set to host the Conference Championship at their new on-campus stadium. Kevin Smith broke more records this game. He had 320 yards, 41 carries, and 4 touchdowns. He became the state of Florida's all-time single season rushing yards leader. He won the ESPN All-America Player of the Week for his effort. {{-}} ===Week 12: Southern Methodist (November 17)=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road='''UCF''' |R1=21 |R2=14 |R3=14 |R4=0 |Home=SMU |H1=10 |H2=3 |H3=7 |H4=0 }} Khymest Williams started the game off with a 99-yard kickoff return for a touchdown for the Knights. After trading scores through the first quarter, UCF took control of the game. Kevin Smith ran in two touchdowns, and Johnell Neal intercepted a pass and ran it back 72 yards for a touchdown in the third quarter. {{-}} ===Week 13: UTEP (November 24)=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=UTEP |R1= 0 |R2= 10 |R3= 7 |R4= 3 |Home='''UCF''' |H1= 0 |H2= 16 |H3= 6 |H4= 14 }} Despite suffering a 100-yard [[interception]] returned for a [[touchdown]], [[UCF]] beat [[UTEP]] 36-20. Aided by two late touchdowns, UCF sealed the victory, their sixth straight. With the win, UCF clinched the [[Conference USA]] East Division crown, and will host the 2007 [[Conference USA Football Championship|C-USA Championship]] against West Division winner [[Tulsa]]. [[Kevin Smith (running back)|Kevin Smith]] rushed for 219 yards, continuing to add to his historic season.{{cite web|title=Tulsa can't contain Smith as UCF clinches first C-USA title|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=273352116|work=ESPN.com|publisher=The Walt Disney Company|date=2007-12-01|accessdate=2007-12-01}} {{-}} ===Week 14: [[Conference USA Football Championship|Conference USA Championship]] (December 1)=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Tulsa |R1= 13 |R2= 10 |R3= 0 |R4= 2 |Home='''UCF''' |H1= 10 |H2= 21 |H3= 6 |H4= 7 }} {{seealso|2007 Conference USA Football Championship Game}} Tulsa and UCF met at the C-USA Championship for the second time; Tulsa beat UCF at the [[Florida Citrus Bowl]] in Downtown Orlando in 2005. Kevin Smith continued his dominance, running for 284 yards with 4 touchdowns. Tulsa kept it close in the first half as UCF's defense seemed slow to get started. In the second half, however, they only scored on a safety. Paul Smith, the Tulsa quarterback, threw for 426 yards and three touchdowns, but also gave up three interceptions. UCF won their first ever conference title in football. Kevin Smith finished the game with 2,448 rushing yards on the season, second all-time for single-season rushing yards in FBS history. Only [[Barry Sanders]], who rushed for 2,628 yards in 1989 for Oklahoma State, has rushed for more yards in a single season. {{-}} ===[[2007 Liberty Bowl|AutoZone Liberty Bowl]] (December 29)=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=UCF |R1=0 |R2=3 |R3=0 |R4=0 |Home='''Mississippi State''' |H1=0 |H2=3 |H3=0 |H4=7 }} With their Conference USA championship, UCF got an automatic berth at the [[AutoZone]] [[Liberty Bowl]] in [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]], [[Tennessee]] on December 29, 2007. It was just their second ever bowl game. They faced [[2007 Mississippi State Bulldogs football team|Mississippi State]] from the [[Southeastern Conference]]. After trading 2nd quarter field goals, neither team scored again until MSU's [[Anthony Dixon]] leapt into the endzone for a one-yard touchdown run with under two minutes remaining to put Mississippi State up by the final score. Kevin Smith tried for Barry Sanders' single-season rushing record but was shy of it by 61 yards, finishing with 119 yards rushing against MSU. He was one of only four players to rush for over 100 yards on MSU's defense all season. {{-}} ==See also== *[[List of UCF Knights football seasons]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{UCF Knights football navbox}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2007 Ucf Knights Football Team}} [[Category:2007 Conference USA football season|UCF]] [[Category:UCF Knights football seasons]] [[Category:Conference USA football champion seasons]]
